caption:
This photograph presents a panoramic view of a wooded valley with a small industrial town nestled within. The foreground features residential homes surrounded by lush greenery, including numerous trees and well-maintained lawns.

Dominating the middle ground are several buildings of various sizes, with the most prominent structure being a large industrial factory from which a white plume of smoke is rising sharply into the sky. This suggests ongoing industrial operations at the time the picture was taken. The industrial area also includes some silos and additional utility buildings that contribute to the functional aspects of the town.

Several train tracks can be seen cutting through the town, indicating the presence of rail transportation which is likely critical for both the residents' connectivity and the industrial activities in the area.

The background is dominated by densely wooded hills in varying shades of green, cradling the town on all sides. This geographic setting likely provides a natural barrier, enclosing the town in a secluded environment.

The overall composition and the play of natural and industrial elements speak to a classic small industrial town scene, balancing residential life with the demands and impacts of industry within a rich natural landscape.
title: Union carbide ferro-Alloy plant seen from deep water.  Total plant emissions decreased from 113,252 tons to 2,649 tons from 1967 to 1975, a drop of 97.7 percent.  The decrease occurred after agreement on a compliance schedule between union carbide and the West Virginia air pollution control commission.  The u.s.  Environmental protection agency stack sampled plant emissions while developing national new source performance standards.  (see images 8566 and 8567)
